channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: Turkey’s Ruling Party Loses Parliamentary Majority
item.description: The election results represent a significant setback to President Recep Tayyip Erdogan and indicate that his efforts to accumulate power have run aground.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO and CEYLAN YEGINSU
item.media:description: A woman prepared to cast her vote in Turkey's parliamentary election at a polling station in Istanbul on Sunday.

item.title: The Brutal Silencing of a Woman at the Forefront of Libya’s Rebellion
item.description: Scores or perhaps hundreds of killings remain unsolved in Benghazi, Libya. But no victim has symbolized the crushed hopes of the Libyan uprising more than Salwa Bugaighis.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: ‘Stripped, Beaten, Humiliated’ and Barred From Her Own Trial in Egypt
item.description: Hend Nafea and several others were dragged, beaten and stripped by Egyptian security forces at another demonstration against military rule in 2011.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: A Quickly Stifled Attempt to Ease Suffering in Bahrain
item.description: The way the government of Bahrain would react to an uprising became clear when security forces rounded up health workers who treated injured protesters.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: KAREEM FAHIM

item.title: Making Herself Heard, Before and After Tunisia’s Uprising
item.description: Before the revolution, Ghazala Mhamdi led the fight for jobs, freedom and human rights, and suffered for it. But when democracy arrived, she ran for Parliament.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: CARLOTTA GALL

item.title: Brides of Syria Were Joined in Opposition to Violence
item.description: In a perilous act of defiance, several women in white, dressed as brides, stood shoulder to shoulder in Damascus and declared, “We want to live.”
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD

item.title: In Yemen, a Brief Moment Before Women Were Pushed Aside Again
item.description: When protesters succeeded in ousting President Ali Abdullah Saleh in 2012, it seemed especially promising for women. But that hope has unraveled.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: KAREEM FAHIM

item.title: SEAL Team 6: A Secret History of Quiet Killings and Blurred Lines
item.description: The unit best known for killing Osama bin Laden has been converted into a global manhunting machine with limited outside oversight.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: MARK MAZZETTI, NICHOLAS KULISH, CHRISTOPHER DREW, SERGE F. KOVALESKI, SEAN D. NAYLOR and JOHN ISMAY
item.media:description: Navy SEAL operators awaited a night mission to capture insurgent leaders near Falluja, Iraq, in July 2007.

item.title: On Sidelines of G-7 Meeting, Obama and Merkel Strengthen Ties
item.description: Though Mr. Obama enjoys an unusually close rapport with Ms. Merkel, their bond has been tested by a complicated intelligence relationship.
item.dc:creator: JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS

item.title: On Sidelines of G-7 Meeting, Obama and Merkel Show That Relations Are Mended
item.description: Though Mr. Obama enjoys an unusually close rapport with Ms. Merkel, their bond has been tested by a complicated intelligence relationship.
item.dc:creator: JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS

item.title: Spanish Tuna Fishing Melds to Japan’s Taste, Reshaping a 3,000-Year-Old Technique
item.description: In response to fishing quotas and consumer demand, companies that run the almadraba are shifting to ranching to help fatten the tuna, rather than lifting and killing their catch.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER
item.media:credit: Laura Leon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Bluefin tuna were surrounded by fishing nets in an ancient technique known as almadraba, as the fishing season opened off southern Spain.

item.title: Special Report: G-7 Summit: No Humans Were Harmed in the Making of This Product
item.description: Group of 7 leaders plan to discuss so-called supply chain standards -- ways of ensuring that everyday products do not come packaged with human misery.
item.dc:creator: JACK EWING
item.media:description: Workers sorting crabs by size at a pier in Samut Sakhon Province, Thailand. The European Union threatened to ban imports of seafood from the country because of concerns about unlawful fishing.

item.title: Special Report: G-7 Summit: Coal in Poland Lowering Life Spans
item.description: Poland has the highest levels in Europe of the tiny pollution particles that are strongly linked to serious health problems like heart attacks, strokes, cancer and even dementia.
item.dc:creator: BETH GARDINER
item.media:description: A coal-fired power plant in Silesia. The European Union has opened proceedings against Poland over air pollution levels.

item.title: Special Report: G-7 Summit: Quirky Bavarian Retreat Opens Up to G-7 Leaders
item.description: A Group of 7 leaders meeting in June will gather at Schloss Elmau, helping to continue the resort's tradition as a crossroads of culture and thought.
item.dc:creator: JACK EWING
item.media:description: Schloss Elmau in Krün, Germany, near the border with Austria. Princes and countesses used to visit to hear about nature and dance.

item.title: MERS Cases Rise in South Korea, Health Officials Say
item.description: The Health Ministry said 64 people had contracted Middle East respiratory syndrome, and five people had died from the disease.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Saudi Arabia Shoots Down Missile Fired From Yemen
item.description: The Saudis said the missile was fired by forces loyal to Yemen’s Houthi rebels. It was the first time Yemeni factions had used the weapon since the conflict began more than two months ago.
item.dc:creator: SHUAIB ALMOSAWA and KAREEM FAHIM

item.title: Get New York Times’ WhatsApp Alerts on Pope’s Latin America Trip
item.description: Subscribe to our new account on WhatsApp to receive updates on the pope’s trip to Latin America and how the leader of the Roman Catholic Church is received.
item.media:description: Pope Francis blessed a child in Rio de Janeiro in 2013.

item.title: Putin Urges Western Pressure on Ukraine in Peace Effort
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia called on the United States and Europe to pressure the Ukrainian government to comply with a cease-fire accord that was reached in February.
item.dc:creator: DAVID M. HERSZENHORN

item.title: Surprising Saudi Rises as a Prince Among Princes
item.description: Prince Mohammed bin Salman, 29, has swiftly accumulated more power than any prince has ever held, and he has become one of Saudi Arabia’s most visible leaders.
item.dc:creator: DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK
item.media:description: Deputy Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman of Saudi Arabia.

item.title: Pope Francis Urges a Divided Bosnia to Heal, Declaring ‘War Never Again!’
item.description: Pope Francis praised the progress Bosnia made since the bloody ethnic conflict of the 1990s and urged an end to the sectarian conflicts around the world.
item.dc:creator: RICK LYMAN
item.media:description: Bosnians greeted Pope Francis on Saturday as he was driven to a stadium in Sarajevo where he said Mass before 65,000 people.
